elements.content: The metal–organic framework MIL-53­(Al) serves as a model system in this study. Its formation mechanism in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) is elucidated through simultaneous FTIR and Raman spectroscopy and turbidity measurements collected under in-situ synthesis conditions in a custom-designed solvothermal reactor coupled with reaction sampling. Different synthesis steps are followed over synthesis time including a prenucleation building unit (PNBU) consisting of one linker molecule and one aluminum atom, the assembly of the PNBUs to MIL-53 nuclei in solution, the decomposition of DMF to formic acid and dimethylammonium, and finally the precipitation of the crystalline MOF phase. The rearrangement of the PNBU to form MIL-53 is identified as the rate-limiting reaction step responsible for the long induction time at low temperatures (<80 °C). MOF nucleation and particle growth is followed directly in-situ through a novel methodcomparison of the temporal evolution of the respective FTIR and Raman bands. Analysis of the particles isolated after various synthesis times indicates that MIL-53­(H2BDC) of low crystalline long-range order is formed initially, which quickly rearranges to form more ordered, crystalline particles with DMF inside of the pores (MIL-53­(DMF)). It is to be expected that the synthesis steps elucidated herein can be generalized to the solvothermal synthesis of other metal–organic framework structures from metal salts and organic acid linkers.

Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a versatile class of highly structured, porous crystalline solids comprised of organic linkers coordinated to metal clusters. Their unique structure endows MOFs with many advantageous characteristics, such as high surface area, highly ordered microporous networks, and the possibility of tailor-made structures. Some structures possess good thermal stability and resistance against moisture, which is an inevitable prerequisite for technical applications. Due to these features, MOFs have the potential to overcome many common limitations in the fields of catalysis, sensing, drug delivery, gas separation, and gas storage.

elements.content: Although there has been much research on the properties of metal–organic frameworks and numerous novel structures have been synthesized to date, there are only few reports focusing on the MOF formation steps prior to precipitation. Optimization of MOF synthesis protocols has in consequence been largely governed by serendipity. An understanding of the individual formation steps would allow for the development of improved strategies for targeted engineering of MOF materials with defined crystal structures tailor-made to fit a variety of specific applications.

elements.content: In-situ studies of metal–organic framework growth to date have employed nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), small- and wide-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS/WAXS), static light scattering, extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and energy dispersive X-ray diffraction (EDXRD) measurements, as well as atomic force microscopy to follow the MOF crystallization process over time. The majority of these studies have focused on the formation kinetics of the MOF Bragg reflections of in-situ EDXRD spectra and deriving the nucleation and growth rates using the Gaultieri equation. In-situ EDXRD is well-suited for following processes involving the formation of a solid crystal phase. However, it cannot be used to directly observe chemical reactions and formation steps within the solvent prior to MOF precipitation. These steps are vital to understanding MOF formation and can be directly followed with in-situ FTIR and Raman spectroscopy. To the best of our knowledge, only one study to date by Ren et al. has employed in-situ IR monitoring to follow the modulated synthesis of Zr-fumarate MOF over time.

elements.content: Only a few studies have been carried out to date on the early stages of MOF formation in solution. Most research was devoted to particular aspects of MOF syntheses. Surblé et al. investigated the formation of MIL-89 starting from an Fe­(III) acetate secondary building unit (SBU) precursor solution. Through ex-situ X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements of isolated, amorphous intermediates they demonstrated that the trimeric metal oxide SBU is retained during MOF synthesis. Cavillon et al. observed with in-situ SAXS/WAXS the formation of clusters 1 nm in diameter shortly after synthesis begin and before the precipitation of the ZIF-8 phase. In a pioneering study, Haouas, Férey, and co-workers identified metal-linker prenucleation building units (PNBUs)a technical term already known from studies on AlPO4–CJ215during the synthesis of aluminum trimesates by means of in-situ liquid-state 27Al and 1H NMR measurements. Based on their results, they proposed a formation pathway leading to the different structures of MIL-96, MIL-100, and MIL-110. Gascon and co-workers demonstrated with in-situ EDXRD and other techniques during MIL synthesis from AlCl3·6H2O and amino-functionalized terephthalic acid the role of water in promoting the formation of the thermodynamically favored product NH2-MIL-53­(Al) instead of the kinetic NH2-MIL-101­(Al) product. Prior to the precipitation of Al-MIL-101-NH2, they observed the formation of amorphous primary particles (<1 nm) with in-situ SAXS/WAXS. Under our experimental conditions, with Al­(NO3)3·9H2O and terephthalic acid as precursors, only the formation of MIL-53­(Al) was observed.

elements.content: During MOF syntheses in amide-based solvents, the solvent has been shown to decompose to the corresponding organic acid and amine. In the case of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), the decomposition process to formic acid and dimethylamine is triggered by elevated solvent temperature, the presence of water, and acidic conditions. However, the exact kinetics of formic acid formation and the temporal relation of this process to the growth of MOF particles remain unstudied.

elements.content: The present work is the first study, to the best of our knowledge, to use simultaneous in-situ IR and Raman spectroscopy and turbidity measurements to study individual reaction steps occurring during the MOF formation process. This is done over the full range of sizes and time scales involved in the process, namely, from the early stages to the final phase formation. MIL-53­(Al), one of the most studied MOFs, serves as a model system and is of particular interest due to its interesting breathing behavior and high thermal stability. Its structure consists of infinite μ-OH corner-sharing AlO4(OH)2 octahedra chains connected by terephthalates which form one-dimensional, rhombic pore channels.

elements.content: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted on a Gemini SEM 500 microscope from Zeiss operated between 0.3 and 0.5 kV. SEM samples were prepared by mixing a 0.3 g/L suspension of MIL-53 in ethanol, sonicating for 10 min, placing a drop on a clean silicon wafer, and allowing to dry at least 8 h at room temperature for the excess ethanol to evaporate. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a TGA 2950 from TA Instruments with a heating ramp of 5 K min–1 in air. Ex-situ Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of the MOF product were recorded using an FTIR-4100 spectrometer from JASCO equipped with a GladiATR attenuated total reflection unit from Pike Technologies. The spectra were collected by the accumulation of 16 scans with a resolution of 4.0 cm–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were taken with an Empyrean diffractometer from PANalytical with a Cu Kα X-ray source operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Measurements were taken between 4 and 50°, with a step size of 0.013°, a scan step time of 10.2 s, and an automatic divergence slit with an irradiated length of 10 mm. N2 sorption isotherms were collected at 77 K on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010. Prior to measurements, the powder samples were outgassed for 20 h at 250 °C. The reagents were stirred at room temperature for at least 20 min until the educts were completely dissolved. The synthesis solution was transferred into the reactor and then heated to the desired synthesis temperature (60–100 °C) over 4 h. Constant stirring conditions were applied with a 45° pitched blade propeller (d = 0.035 m) at 240 rpm and Re number of 11,000. The reaction mixture was kept at the reaction temperature for another 20 h and then cooled to room temperature over 30 min through the use of a cooling jacket. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, particles were isolated via centrifugation. The samples were washed with deionized water by three centrifugation and redispersion cycles. Finally, a portion of the product was calcined at 400 °C for 18 h in order to remove guest molecules from the pores.

Synthesis

MIL-53(Al) was synthesized in a 1.5 L solvothermal Büchi Versoclave Type 3E reactor from C3 Prozess- and Analysentechnik GmbH with connections for in-situ turbidity, FTIR, and Raman probes (Figure S1). Samples were taken during the synthesis with a homemade sampling system and immediately quenched with cold water to prevent further reaction. For the synthesis, 0.165 mol of terephthalic acid (H2BDC) and 0.33 mol of Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O were mixed in 1 L of DMF. The reagents were stirred at room temperature for at least 20 min until the educts were completely dissolved. The synthesis solution was transferred into the reactor and then heated to the desired synthesis temperature (60-100 °C) over 4 h. Constant stirring conditions were applied with a 45° pitched blade propeller (d = 0.035 m) at 240 rpm and Re number of 11,000. The reaction mixture was kept at the reaction temperature for another 20 h and then cooled to room temperature over 30 min through the use of a cooling jacket. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, particles were isolated via centrifugation. The samples were washed with deionized water by three centrifugation and redispersion cycles. Finally, a portion of the product was calcined at 400 °C for 18 h in order to remove guest molecules from the pores.

elements.content: The MIL-53 crystallization rate was modeled with the Avrami equation, α = 1 – exp­[−k(t – t o)] m , with α being the normalized MIL-53 ν C–H band area at 1148 cm–1. By linearizing the equation to ln­[−ln­(1 – α)] = m·ln­(t – t 0) + m·ln­(k) and constructing a Sharp–Hancock plot (b), the Avrami exponent m and rate constant k were determined for each synthesis temperature (c). The activation energy was calculated from k values at varying temperatures through application of the Arrhenius equation ln ( k ) = − E a R · 1 T + const (d). The determined activation energy was 90.4 kJ mol–1 (d), which falls in the range of the values previously determined for MIL-101, HKUST-1, ZIF-8, and MOF-14 via in-situ XRD. The MIL-53 synthesis carried out between 60 and 100 °C has an Avrami exponent, m, between 1.0 and 1.4, indicative of a first-order boundary-controlled reaction. Synthesis experiments in which the MIL-53 formation rate was shown to be heavily dependent on temperature (a) but not on the stirring rate (Figure S5) demonstrate that MIL-53 formation is reaction-rate-controlled and not diffusion-controlled. The fact that m does not change appreciably with increasing temperature implies a temperature-independent growth mechanism.

elements.content: The formation of metal–linker complexes (PNBUs) in solution as primary building blocks during hydrothermal MOF syntheses was previously detected by Haouas et al. They identified different aluminum–trimesate PNBUs which lead to the formation of MIL-96, MIL-100, and MIL-110 via the change of the 27Al chemical shifts in the in-situ recorded 27Al NMR spectra. Employing DFT calculations, Cantu et al. proposed that the first PNBU formation step during the assembly of MIL-101, which is identical with the first MIL-53 formation step, namely, the [M­(H2O)4–HBDC]2+ complexation, should have a comparatively low activation energy. In consequence, this first formation step should be fast. The subsequent formation step of MIL-101 was proposed to be the rate-limiting step. It involves the junction of two separate [M­(H2O)4–HBDC]2+ PNBUs via μ-OH. Furthermore, the coordination state of one terephthalate changes from being chelating bidentate to bridging bismonodentate. This second step is also required for the formation of MIL-53 from the PNBU [Al­(H2O)4–HBDC]2+.

elements.content: The FTIR MOF bands were found to originate from both–colloidal MIL-53­(Al) nuclei and precipitated MOF particles. The relative contribution from colloidal nuclei species was found to be much larger than that originating from the solid MOF phase. To demonstrate this, samples were taken from the solution at various times during synthesis and allowed to cool to room temperature. The FTIR spectra of these samples were then recorded, and the integrated area of the ω C–H vibration at 755 cm–1 was plotted as a function of synthesis time (a). In contrast to the trend observed during in-situ measurements, the area of the ω C–H vibration of the solid MIL-53­(Al) phase at 755 cm–1 increased logarithmically with time and exhibited no local maximum at 3.5 h. The discrepancy between the area of the ω C–H band at 755 cm–1 determined by in-situ measurements (and normalized to 25 °C using the relation displayed in Figure S4) and the sampled reaction solution is caused by the formation of MOF nuclei with an intense FTIR signal starting at 3 h. These are so small as to either precipitate to form crystalline MOF or to disintegrate in solution upon cooling. This is supported by the fact that the synthesis mixture taken at 3.5 h, when the FTIR MOF bands exhibit their maximum intensity, appeared slightly turbid, and only trace amounts of solid MIL-53­(Al) could be isolated, even after centrifugation for 10 min at 14,000 rpm.

This could either be due to the reduced penetration depth of the FTIR probe with a diamond tip, which is 3.5 μm at 755 cm–1 as compared to that of the Raman probewhich is 12 μm for a light source with a wavelength of 785 nmor be due to the fact that the FTIR signal originates from the induced dipole moment while the Raman signal originates from changes in polarizability. The MIL-53 concentration at this time is too low to be detected with in-situ Raman. Thus, through careful combination of in-situ FTIR and Raman spectroscopy it is possible to deconvolute the nucleation and growth steps of crystal growth, provided the material is spectroscopically both IR and Raman active.

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction pattern (b) indicates a rise in crystallinity of MIL-53­(DMF) particles isolated between 3.6 and 3.9 h. Although the sample taken at 3.6 h consists of small nanoparticles, the sorption isotherm at 77 K (after calcination) shows a high nitrogen uptake at low relative pressures corresponding to the presence of micropores (d). The calculated BET area of 897 m2 g–1 for the sample taken at 3.6 h accounts for approximately two-thirds of the accessible surface area reported for hydrothermally synthesized MIL-53. All nitrogen isotherms (d) show an additional uptake above p/p 0 > 0.9 and a more or less pronounced hysteresis loop, which is caused most likely by nitrogen condensation in the interstitial voids between the nanoparticles. The isotherm of the sample taken at 3.6 h, however, displays a type H4 loop with a forced hysteresis loop closure around p/p 0 ≈ 0.45. This phenomenonreferred to in the literature as the tensile strength effectis often observed when microporous crystals such as zeolites form disordered aggregates. We conclude that at the onset of precipitation MIL-53 platelet nanocrystals aggregate in a disordered way, creating interparticulate pores in the nanometer range. We suppose that the cavities are connected to the outer surface of the aggregates by the MOF micropores, thus forming an ink-bottle pore network. Consequently, the MOF pores (bottle necks) prevent the depletion of the inner voids, until the desorption branch reaches a critical p/p 0 value (p/p 0 ≈ 0.4 to 0.5 for N2 at 77 K) and the cavities are instantly emptied by cavitation-induced effects.

elements.content: The formation of nuclei in solution and precipitation to form crystalline MOF can be monitored in-situ through the growth and disappearance of characteristic bands in the FTIR spectrum, which was experimentally found to be more sensitive to the liquid than the solid phase. A rapid burst of nucleation can thus be observed before the formation of solid MIL-53. This process is accompanied by a rise in pH* due to the basicity of the hydrolysis product dimethylamine. By using the linear relation of the FTIR and Raman band intensities with regards to species concentration and by taking the negative linear effect of temperature on the intensity of the spectral bands into account, it is possible to quantify the amount of formic acid and metal–organic framework formed during solvothermal synthesis.

Shortly after the emergence of MOF nuclei in solution, an FTIR band identified as ν C-OH (1185 cm-1) of formic acid becomes visible (c). This band increases shortly after formation of the MOF nuclei in solution, rising sharply between 3 and 4 h before leveling off at around 4.2 h to reach a final area corresponding to a formic acid concentration of 0.44 mol L-1.

The X-ray diffraction pattern (b) indicates a rise in crystallinity of MIL-53(DMF) particles isolated between 3.6 and 3.9 h. The isotherm of the sample taken at 3.6 h, however, displays a type H4 loop with a forced hysteresis loop closure around p/p 0 ~ 0.45. This phenomenonreferred to in the literature as the tensile strength effectis often observed when microporous crystals such as zeolites form disordered aggregates. We suppose that the cavities are connected to the outer surface of the aggregates by the MOF micropores, thus forming an ink-bottle pore network. Consequently, the MOF pores (bottle necks) prevent the depletion of the inner voids, until the desorption branch reaches a critical p/p 0 value (p/p 0 ~ 0.4 to 0.5 for N2 at 77 K) and the cavities are instantly emptied by cavitation-induced effects.
